title: What will be the approval rate for Japan's cabinet in NHK's monthly survey in September 2017?
preds: The question resolved earlier today at 44%
Recent North Korean provocation is likely to rally citizens around their leadership; recent reports note the approval rating has soared back over 50%
TOKYO (Reuters) - Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s support ratings have recovered to the 50 percent level, a poll released on Tuesday showed.

NK fired missiles over Japan in 1998, 2009, and 2016.  In those cases, the cabinet approval rating respectively dropped by 14, increased by 12, and increased by 4. Whether you throw out the two extremes, or allow them to cancel each other out, it wouldn’t be unreasonable to assume the current rating would increase by around 4. Also, Abe has replaced the defense minister and re-shuffled his cabinet in an effort to increase his (and his cabinet’s) approval rating.  It’s not unreasonable to assume the public reaction would be positive, rather than negative. Additionally, the approval rating was 58% just 7 months ago.  I think there’s an argument to be made for regression to the mean after the steep decline due to the defense minister scandal. Offsetting these arguments is the Kyodo poll showing no change in the approval rating.  While the two polls do seem to swing around each other, sometimes by as much as 5 points, it’s a valid concern. My nervous gut says 43 is the number, but I’ll be hedging my bets.

monthly average approval rating for the last 3 years is between 46-49. SD over the last 3 years is roughly 5. regression towards the mean is always a consideration with these types of polls. and the longer we go from a 'scandal' the less it has a negative influence- unless of course a new scandal emerges. Lastly, economic data coming out is positive for Japan, which often has a positive impact on approval ratings.
As long as Mr. Kim keeps behaving as he is and Japan feels threatened, those in power become more popular.

The cabinet reshuffle he made in August 3 seems to have helped improve the tendency of the approval rate. But the scandals to new prominent members in his cabinet and potential change in policies will increase the uncertainty of a population with a hight risk aversion.

The approval rating for the cabinet has dropped substantially since the start of the year. It started at 55% and is currently at 39% (according to the NHK website). This suggests that the approval rating will remain below 46% as there hasn't been such a large increase or decrease in % in any month of this year.  August's cabinet reshuffle has had a positive impact upon approval ratings - a change in direction that makes approval ratings increasing in September more likely than decreasing.  I suspect that a small increase in September is likely, based on rate of change across the months of the year so far and based on the recent upward trajectory, putting approval ratings at about 41%.
Currently at 39%, large recent drop. Unlikely to recover quickly, so 37-41 is most likely. Variation over a year is about 10% so could end up above or below, more likely above given history.

Here's a trend analysis from Japan Macro Advisors, where they tally their own cabinet approval rating using 7 different organizations including NHK: Recent data trend The approval rate for PM Abe recovered modestly in August, according to various polls taken over the weekend of August 4-6. The trimmed average of 7 polls we track shows the approval rate improving to 38.7% in August from 34.2% in July. Disapproval rate fell to 46.5% in August from 50.8% in July.   While PM Abe must have preferred a larger bump to his approval rate, the poll results in  August must be encouraging for PM Abe. The cabinet reshuffle he made in August 3 seems to have helped change the conversation from scandals to new prominent members in his cabinet and potential change in policies. There has also been a lack of fresh materials on the multiple scandals involving Prime Minister himself and his protege ex-Defense Minister Inada in the past two weeks. The parliament is in recess and the main opposition party, DPJ, is also yet to choose its new leader after the resignation of its previous leader, Ms. Renho at the end of July. PM Abe's hope must be that scandals will somehow go away, giving him a chance to steer the focus of the public back to economic issues where he has been relatively successful in grasping the mind of the nation. https://www.japanmacroadvisors.com/page/category/politics/cabinet-approval-rating/

Lack of any fresh scandals, the approval ratings should receive a minor bump upwards and trend towards the average.

Abe's approval has been recovering from a series of scandals earlier in the year and a cabinet reshuffle earlier this month seems to have reversed the downward trend. As long as no new scandals occur I think the cabinet continues to slowly return to a mean around 50%.

Up: Since the last two surveys were taken, cabinet reshuffle seems to have raised approval ratings by a few percentage points.  He probably has some room to make up to get to his pre-scandal high.
Solidarity with North Korea threat looming could raise approval Down:  If school scandals continue to hit, they could reduce approval dramatically again

This is a very slightly educated guess. An August 28 editorial in the Japan Times about the far right mentions "decline in popular support for the Abe administration." But the cabinet reshuffle at the beginning of August could improve ratings over the low numbers in June and July. So could continued economic growth (4% annualized Q2 growth reported in mid-August, with strong consumer spending).

The Japanese are showing military nationalism for the first time since WWII and the Japanese are a proud warrior culture.  The current conflict with the DPRK has been handled with verbal aggression and the real possibility of Japan being able to determine their course of war, if necessary, with much less US assistance.  They are now in a position to decide when a war is necessary and I believe that will improve approval ratings of politicians.
